poem:
### The Game of Ink and Paper

The inked rivers flow,  
bound between columns,  
woven in eras of empire's echo,  
Lord Rothermere in his high-backed chair,  
shuffles whispering paper cards—  
he deals with time's hand,  
while headlines tilt like kite tails  
in the brisk British air,  
a nation nodding in rhythm,  
to the rightward drift.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Lord Rothermere’s Telegraph takeover strengthens UK media’s rightwing tilt As the dust settles from the battle for the ownership of the Daily Telegraph, one man has been left standing: Lord Rothermere, whose family have been a mainstay of British newspapers for more than a century. “This is a very British stitch-up,” said Lionel Barber, the former editor of the Financial Times. “Lord Rothermere has played a very astute poker hand, he’s shown patience and he’s". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
